ATHLETIC BOARD
FACES A CRISIS
Problem to Meet Obligations on

BASEBALL MAY BE DROPPED
One Sport at Hopkins Will Have
to be Given up.
Football Season Netted only $100 Against
$1200 for Last Year Not Enough
Money to Support the Other
Teams—A Committee is
Considering the
Problem.

The finances of the Johns Hopkins University Athletic Association are in a serious condition, so
serious in fact that either obligations to the University trustees
tmast be repudiated, a subscription
taken among the students, or one
of the University teams—probably
baseball—dropped for this year in
order to enable the Association to
Pull through by the narrowest margin. It was announced Saturday
that a student mass meeting will
be held one day this week in order
to discuss the problem.
The crisis in the financial affairs
of the Association was caused by
the fact that the football season
netted only one-twelfth of what it
did last season. As football is the
best paying sport at Hopkins, it
has to be relied on to help the other
teams out. Three hundred dollars
(or less) will be turned over to
Treasurer Stewart. by Manager
Haynes. From this $300 must be
subtracted $175 advanced by the
board, leaving about $roo clear.
Last year the amount turned over
was $1,400.
If the Board had no obligations
other than those of financing the
teams, the problem would be a
comparatively simple one. But
there are two magnificent stands
at Homewood which the Association is expected to pay for. The
Cost of each was about $8,000, and
if $1,500 could be turned over
every year, as was the case last
season, the whole $16,00o would
soon be wiped out.
To do the best it can, and to at
least pay the interest on the cost
of the second stand and something
toward the sinking fund, the Athletic Association is morally obligated. The proposition was made
to the trustees of the University
last spring to put up the second
stand, as it was thought that it
would be paying venture and that
the added proceeds from the games

The trustees on account of the fact
that they had a fair deficit to
deal with, did not at first take
kindly to the proposal of going
farther in debt. Mr. Blanchard
Randall, however, was in favor of
it. He had had the case presented
to him by a committee of the alumni, and the trustees allowed him
to go ahead. The understanding
was, however, that the Athletic
Association was to pay the interest
and somethingon the principal. This
according to present prospects they
will be unable to do, and the Board
will be forced to tell the trustees
that because football didn't pay,
very little can be paid on account
of the two concrete stands.
Now, why didn't football pay?
There certainly were larger crowds
than last year, except at the St.
John's game. The gross receipts
were $2,opo greater. The team
was better than ever before.
Of course, we are fully aware
that the team had to pay $850 more
for coaches than was the case last
year when the alumni footed the
larger part of the bill. But leaving
this out of consideration, there
ought to have been a larger net gain
than $100. Nearly $500 was expended on a training table, which
valuable as it may be, used up half
a thousand dollars, which would
have more than paid the interest
on one stand.
Then there is the item of $900
for equipment. It was one-third
of this amount last year, and no
one will say that the team under
the management of Coach Gill was
hampered by a lack of adequate
clothes or shoes. Then there was
a little expense of $30 for a dinner
at the Belvedere.
Let it be distinctly understood
that we are not fixing the blame
for this, and let it be doubly clear
that we are not criticising Manager
Haynes for the smallness of the
a/mount which he turned over to
the Board: He was not responsible
for the expenditures. It was his
only to pay the bills after they
were contracted, and then to try
and save as much as he could from
the remnants.
The Athletic Board certainly
ought here to come in for some
criticism. They once, earlier in
the year, foresaw the probable deficit and passed a resolution that
a training table would be too heavy
an expense, and then later when it
was again urged, rescinded action
and placed the matter in the hands
of the football authorities, who decided in favor of the free feed.

The lacrosse season of 1911
opened on Thursday, December 8,
when an organization meeting was
held in the trophy room at 5
o'clock. Very interesting speeches
were made by Captain Eddie Hulbert, head coach Charles Meyer,
who was captain. of 1906 team,
assistant coach Henry Frank, who
was captain of the 1909 team,
assistant coach. "Bob" Lowndes,
"Bill' Schmeisser, the old Hopkins
star, who is author of the book
"How to Play Lacrosse," and who
is at present president of the
National Lacrosse Association, and
Pitts Raleigh, who is one of the
lacrosse advisers.
Captain Hulbert spoke on
what Hopkins has done in lacrosse. Coach Meyer named the
necessary qualifications of the men
who are coming out for the team
and showed that men are needed
of different height and weight for
various positions.
Assistant coach Frank spoke a
few words, saying that they, the
alumni, came to the meeting with
one ambition; and that was to get
the lost championship back.
Assistant coach Lowndes spoke
a few words, saying that if the men
gave the best they had in them,
the coaches would do the rest.
"Bill' Schmeisser started to talk
for five minutes only, on what
kind of men we want on the team.
There are two requirements: first,
that the men should be gentlemen;
and secondly, that they work.
Pitts Raleigh cracked a bundle
of jokes and then took his seat.
The first regular practice will be
on Saturday at 3.30, in the "cage."

Once more the ominuous roar of
distant thunder grows louder in
our ears! Once more the discreet
student begins to treat his intellectual war-proof art of successive doses of midnight oil against
the coming of the storm! Examination time is drawing near!
But, to be serious, as the first
of the three great yearly tests
approaches, it might be worth
while to consider what is the purpose and achievement of such tests.
We are in the habit of looking
upon examinations as completely
inseparable from a college education. What part do they play in
such an education? Why have we
come to look upon them as inseparable therefrom? These questions
might be timely.
A college education, we think
everyone will admit, ought to serve
two purposes—to supply a man
with a certain amount of teaching
and to fit him for life. All the
machinery, therefore, of college
education ought to work towards
one or both of these ends. Towards which do examinations
work, and how?
Of old, the greater part of a
man's learning, whether acquired at
college or elsewhere, was acquired
through the memory. If a man
wanted to learn Latin, he memorized Lilly's grammar. If he wanted to learn geometry, he memorized
Euclid's five books. The only
way in which a professor could
judge whether the student's memory was retaining the vast amount
of education which it swallowed
daily was by periodical examinations. In recent years the whole
theory of education has changed.
The student is urged to learn
more with his reason, and with his
memory less. If he is learning
geometry, he acquaints himself with
Euclid's theorems, but, instead of
memorizing them, applies them to
the solution of original problems.
If he is learning Latin, he acquaints himself with the chief
rules of grammar and commences
straightway to apply them to the
process of translation.
Consequently, examinations also
have altered their character. They
consist no longer merely of questions which require the use of the
memory. They demand the exercise
of reason. But as a dile the conditions under which they are held
are not just those most conducive
to the exercise of reason. The
formality which broods over them,

the consciousness of a reputation
which through them, can be lost
but never gained, and above all

weight, have sufficed at the critical moment to surprise memory.
And how much more easily surprised is reason! The ability to
expect an examination with complacency and endure it without
fear is a proof either of disregard
of reputation or of stolidity of
temper. The true scholar seldom
possesses these qualities.
The very difficulty, perhaps in
the use of reason under the circumstances of an examination often
induces examiners to revert to questions which require only the use
of the memory. But such a course,
besides being a return to antiquated
standards, gives opportunity for
the students to use in their paper
that very spurious kind of knowledge which can be acquired by
cramming.
But this cramming i,tself, it is
argued, and the stolidity, or rather
firmness, of temper necessitated by
examinations, make them, if less
tests of acquired learning, at any
rate more perfect instruments in
the training for life. Life is a
competition. Moreover there are
many occasions when a man must
acquire for a particular occasion
a great deal of knowledge for
which he will have no further use.
This is quite true. But in life
the competition is generally open.
Every competitor has his own supporters to encourage him. He sees
just how far his opponent has gone,
and puts forth all his strength to
go farther.
He crams spontaneously (for after all there is so
much cramming done in the world
that examinations hardly seem
necessary to teach us how to do
it). His whole heart is in the
struggle. He revels in it. Nobody
ever revelled in an examination
any more than in a secret fight
with a panther, deep in the loneliness of a mountain cave. In.life
the struggles are open. And it is
probably because examinations are
not open that the general public
admires the man who wears an
"H" more than the man who wears
a Phi Beta Kappa key.
Examinations evidently, therefore, possess several disadvantages
as tests of schorlarship; they possess several disadvantages as aids
in the training for life; what then
do they accomplish in college education? They serve a mighty purpose: they give a man a mark!
But of marks more hereafter.

Once more the ominuous roar of
distant thunder grows louder in
our ears! Once more the discreet
student begins to treat his intellectual war-proof art of successive doses of midnight oil against
the coming of the storm! Examination time is drawing near!
But, to be serious, as the first
of the three great yearly tests
approaches, it might be worth
while to consider what is the purpose and achievement of such tests.
We are in the habit of looking
upon examinations as completely
inseparable from a college education. What part do they play in
such an education? Why have we
come to look upon them as inseparable therefrom? These questions
might be timely.
A college education, we think
everyone will admit, ought to serve
two purposes—to supply a man
with a certain amount of teaching
and to fit him for life. All the
machinery, therefore, of college
education ought to work towards
one or both of these ends. Towards which do examinations
work, and how?
Of old, the greater part of a
man's learning, whether acquired at
college or elsewhere, was acquired
through the memory. If a man
wanted to learn Latin, he memorized Lilly's grammar. If he wanted to learn geometry, he memorized
Euclid's five books. The only
way in which a professor could
judge whether the student's memory was retaining the vast amount
of education which it swallowed
daily was by periodical examinations. In recent years the whole
theory of education has changed.
The student is urged to learn
more with his reason, and with his
memory less. If he is learning
geometry, he acquaints himself with
Euclid's theorems, but, instead of
memorizing them, applies them to
the solution of original problems.
If he is learning Latin, he acquaints himself with the chief
rules of grammar and commences
straightway to apply them to the
process of translation.
Consequently, examinations also
have altered their character. They
consist no longer merely of questions which require the use of the
memory. They demand the exercise
of reason. But as a dile the conditions under which they are held
are not just those most conducive
to the exercise of reason. The
formality which broods over them,

And how much more easily surprised is reason! The ability to

The very difficulty, perhaps in

of the memory. But such a course,
besides being a return to antiquated

cramming.
But this cramming i,tself, it is

rate more perfect instruments in

competition. Moreover there are
many occasions when a man must
acquire for a particular occasion
a great deal of knowledge for
which he will have no further use.
This is quite true. But in life
the competition is generally open.
Every competitor has his own supporters to encourage him. He sees
just how far his opponent has gone,
and puts forth all his strength to
go farther.
He crams spontaneously (for after all there is so
much cramming done in the world
that examinations hardly seem

ever revelled in an examination
any more than in a secret fight
with a panther, deep in the loneliness of a mountain cave. In.life
the struggles are open. And it is
probably because examinations are
not open that the general public
admires the man who wears an
"H" more than the man who wears
a Phi Beta Kappa key.

Upon the suggestion of the Educational Alliance, the New York
County Lawyers' Association has
undertaken to give a series of lectures and addresses on the ethical
aspect of the various branches of
law during the coming winter. In
September of this year, Xenjamin
Tuska, chairman of the Law Committee of the Educational Alliance,
wrote to Charles Strauss, the secretary of the New York County Lawyers' Association, stating that if
the latter Association would undertake to establish such a series of
lectures, the large auditorium and
the smaller lecture halls of the Educational Alliance would be at the
disposal of the Association for that
purpose, and that the directors of
the Educational Alliance would be
glad to co-operate with the Association in securing attendance at such
lectures. The Board of Directors
of the New York County Lawyers'
Association approved of this plan,

Professional Ethics, with power to
act. This committee has taken up
the work and is prosecuting it
through a suly-committee, consisting
of Charles A. Boston, chairman;

Putney. This sub-committee is acting in conjunction with the Law
Committee of the Educational Alliance, which consists of Mr. Tuska

Frank and Louis Marshall. Messrs.
Boston, Abbot and Putney have
volunteered to act as speakers, as
have also the following members
of the New York County Lawyers'
Association: Everett P. Wheeler,
Abraham L. Gutman and Dudley
Field Malone.
The lectures are designed not for
lawyers only, but for laymen as
well, with the idea of informing
people in general what they, as
clients, have the right to expect of
lawyers in the way of protecting
their interests.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

DEAR SIR:—I consider that the

giving of the "H's" this year by
the Athletic Board was the rankest
injustice and the worst case of
bootlicking that I have seen around
the University in a long time.
Personally I cannot conceive on
what ground they could possibly
call it fair to award an "H" to
Jack, who played only 21 minutes
in the Haverford game, and fortyfive minutes in the St. Johns game,
and not to Paulus and Tappan who
played a part of every game during
the season.
It seems to me that having an
unusual condition on one hand,
namely—men playing who have
already played four years at other
colleges, it must be counterbalanced
by something on the other hand ;
that is, recompense in some way the
men whose places they have taken.
That is the undergraduates should
also have an "H" who in the natural
order of things would have had
positions if it hadn't been for the
medical men.
Another thing that has to be taken
into account is that under the new
rules, when a man can go back into
the game again, it is almost an
absolute necessity for a team to
have twd sets of backs—let alone
the other positions—neither of
which could be considered substitute.
And lastly I think there is a condition which will become more
noticeable next year. That is, in
the natural order of things, a man
who has played three years on the
scrub and as substitute, would if
he were any good at all, make the
varsity the next year simply due
to the amount of coaching that he
has had, if nothing else.
For instance in an ordinary college, say eight men come out in
their freshmen year, six will survive to the second year, four to the
third, and three to the fourth, all
three of whom should make the varsity that year. While here under
the present conditions, it doesn't do
a man any good to be the senior
candidate for the position and have
practiced for that position for three
years, for new medical men will
be brought out each year, who will
get the position quite as much on
account of the prestige accorded
them as coming from the medical
school as for their playing abilities.
Therefore it will not take more
than two years for the scrub team
to dwindle to the freshman candidates only, as nobody would come
out a number of years in succession
when there would be no chance
for him on the varsity.
Thank you for the space accorded me in publishing this.
